elements.content: Two new three-dimensional europium(III) dicarboxylates, MIL-79 or Eu(III) 5(OH)9(H2O)6(O2C−C2H2−CO2)3·9.5H2O, and MIL-80 or EuIII 4(OH)4(H2O)5(O2C−C2H2−CO2)4·4H2O, have been obtained under hydrothermal conditions. Both structures, which have been determined using either X-ray powder or single-crystal diffraction data, are built-up from unusual complex chains made from clusters of eight-, nine-, and ten-coordinated europium(III) polyhedra linked through fumarate and maleate dianions. This creates three-dimensional structures with either 1-D large elongated pore channels (MIL-79) or cages (MIL-80) filled in both cases with free water molecules which interact with terminal water molecules or apical oxygen atoms from the carboxylates. The thermal behavior of MIL-79 has been investigated using TGA and X-ray thermodiffractometry and reveals that its dehydration leads to an irreversible pore contraction. Study of the luminescence properties of the yttrium(III) form of MIL-79 doped with europium(III) reveals a significant red-emission upon VUV radiation. Crystal data for MIL-79:  monoclinic space group C2/m with a = 25.954(1) Å, b = 11.014(1) Å, c = 13.247(1) Å, β = 119.162(1)°, and Z = 4. Crystal data for MIL-80:  triclinic space group P1̄ with a = 10.5770(2) Å, b = 10.6164(2) Å, c = 14.9403(3) Å, α = 91.624(1)°, β = 91.120(1)°, γ = 113.892(1)°, and Z = 2.
elements.clean_text: Two new three-dimensional europium(III) dicarboxylates, MIL-79 or Eu(III) 5(OH)9(H2O)6(O2C-C2H2-CO2)3⋅9.5H2O, and MIL-80 or EuIII 4(OH)4(H2O)5(O2C-C2H2-CO2)4⋅4H2O, have been obtained under hydrothermal conditions. Both structures, which have been determined using either X-ray powder or single-crystal diffraction data, are built-up from unusual complex chains made from clusters of eight-, nine-, and ten-coordinated europium(III) polyhedra linked through fumarate and maleate dianions. This creates three-dimensional structures with either 1-D large elongated pore channels (MIL-79) or cages (MIL-80) filled in both cases with free water molecules which interact with terminal water molecules or apical oxygen atoms from the carboxylates. The thermal behavior of MIL-79 has been investigated using TGA and X-ray thermodiffractometry and reveals that its dehydration leads to an irreversible pore contraction. Study of the luminescence properties of the yttrium(III) form of MIL-79 doped with europium(III) reveals a significant red-emission upon VUV radiation. Crystal data for MIL-79: monoclinic space group C2/m with a = 25.954(1) Å, b = 11.014(1) Å, c = 13.247(1) Å, β = 119.162(1)°, and Z = 4. Crystal data for MIL-80: triclinic space group P1̄ with a = 10.5770(2) Å, b = 10.6164(2) Å, c = 14.9403(3) Å, α = 91.624(1)°, β = 91.120(1)°, γ = 113.892(1)°, and Z = 2.

elements.content: Two new open-framework europium(III) dicarboxylates (MIL-79 and MIL-80) have been characterized from X-ray powder or crystal data. Their three-dimensional structures are built up from unusual chains of europium(III) clusters related through fumarate and maleate moieties. This creates three-dimensional pores or cage system filled with free water molecules. The isostuctural yttrium form of MIL-79 doped with europium has been synthesized and exhibits a significant fluorescence red-orange activity in the solid state at room temperature.
elements.clean_text: Two new open-framework europium(III) dicarboxylates (MIL-79 and MIL-80) have been characterized from X-ray powder or crystal data. Their three-dimensional structures are built up from unusual chains of europium(III) clusters related through fumarate and maleate moieties. This creates three-dimensional pores or cage system filled with free water molecules. The isostuctural yttrium form of MIL-79 doped with europium has been synthesized and exhibits a significant fluorescence red-orange activity in the solid state at room temperature.

elements.content:
MIL for Material Institut Lavoisier.

Introduction

Porous solids with either purely inorganic or organic−inorganic hybrid skeletons are currently very topical, owing to their usual applications in ion-exchange, gas separation, catalysis, and more recently in hydrogen storage. The recent introduction of transition metals in the framework of hybrid solids has increased the range of possible applications using their electronic and magnetic properties, but most of the hybrid solids discovered up to now are coordination polymers in which the metallic moieties are either single polyhedra or isolated small clusters, which in most cases drastically decrease their performances and/or the thermal stability required for applicable properties. For such a purpose, the challenge is to increase the dimensionality of the inorganic sub-network which can be either 1D or 2D. This was recently performed in our group for magnetic hybrid solids and this can be applied too for materials for optics.
elements.clean_text:
MIL for Material Institut Lavoisier.

Introduction

Porous solids with either purely inorganic or organic-inorganic hybrid skeletons are currently very topical, owing to their usual applications in ion-exchange, gas separation, catalysis, and more recently in hydrogen storage. The recent introduction of transition metals in the framework of hybrid solids has increased the range of possible applications using their electronic and magnetic properties, but most of the hybrid solids discovered up to now are coordination polymers in which the metallic moieties are either single polyhedra or isolated small clusters, which in most cases drastically decrease their performances and/or the thermal stability required for applicable properties. For such a purpose, the challenge is to increase the dimensionality of the inorganic sub-network which can be either 1D or 2D. This was recently performed in our group for magnetic hybrid solids and this can be applied too for materials for optics.

elements.content: In this domain, the best cations are obviously rare-earths. Some 3D coordination polymers are known using these elements associated with dicarboxylates, sulfonates, and bipyridine N-oxide. Our group recently reported a series of rare-earth solids built up from one- or two-dimensional inorganic sub-networks and aliphatic carbon chains such as diphosphonates, carboxyphosphonates, and di- and tri-carboxylates. The aim is now to create hybrids associating rare-earths and organic rigid moieties that can enhance optical properties (here the fumarates or maleates with their π electrons) and look at their respective influences on the luminescence properties.
elements.clean_text: In this domain, the best cations are obviously rare-earths. Some 3D coordination polymers are known using these elements associated with dicarboxylates,  sulfonates, and bipyridine N-oxide. Our group recently reported a series of rare-earth solids built up from one- or two-dimensional inorganic sub-networks and aliphatic carbon chains such as diphosphonates, carboxyphosphonates, and di- and tri-carboxylates. The aim is now to create hybrids associating rare-earths and organic rigid moieties that can enhance optical properties (here the fumarates or maleates with their π electrons) and look at their respective influences on the luminescence properties.

elements.content: This paper deals with the synthesis, and the structure from either X-ray powder or crystal data, of two new three-dimensional open framework europium(III) carboxylates with unusual one-dimensional inorganic networks:  MIL-79 or Eu(III) 5(OH)9(H2O)6(O2C−C2H2−CO2)3·9.5H2O, and MIL-80 or EuIII 4(OH)4(H2O)5(O2C−C2H2−CO2)4·4H2O. The structure determination of both solids as well as the thermal behavior and the luminescence properties of the yttrium(III) form of MIL-79 doped with europium(III) are reported.
elements.clean_text: This paper deals with the synthesis, and the structure from either X-ray powder or crystal data, of two new three-dimensional open framework europium(III) carboxylates with unusual one-dimensional inorganic networks: MIL-79 or Eu(III) 5(OH)9(H2O)6(O2C-C2H2-CO2)3⋅9.5H2O, and MIL-80 or EuIII 4(OH)4(H2O)5(O2C-C2H2-CO2)4⋅4H2O. The structure determination of both solids as well as the thermal behavior and the luminescence properties of the yttrium(III) form of MIL-79 doped with europium(III) are reported.

elements.content: MIL-79 and MIL-80 were first prepared by mixing at room-temperature europium nitrate Eu(NO3)3·6H2O (Aldrich, 99.9%), fumaric acid HO2C−C2H2−CO2H (Aldrich, 99%), sodium hydroxide (Alfa, 97%), and deionized water in the following ratios:  1:0.5:2.75:180 for MIL-79 and 1:1:2.5:180 for MIL-80. The resulting gels were aged at 120 °C for 3 days in a Teflon-lined PARR bomb and cooled to room temperature. The pH remained acidic throughout the synthesis in both cases (pH 2−3). The white solids were filtered, washed, and dried at room temperature. The yttrium form doped with europium MIL-79(Y, Eu) was prepared using the same synthesis conditions as MIL-79 but substituting 98% of the initial europium nitrate precursor by yttrium nitrate Y(NO3)3·5H2O (Aldrich, 99.9%).
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

 MIL-79 and MIL-80 were first prepared by mixing at room-temperature europium nitrate Eu(NO3)3⋅6H2O (Aldrich, 99.9%), fumaric acid HO2C-C2H2-CO2H (Aldrich, 99%), sodium hydroxide (Alfa, 97%), and deionized water in the following ratios: 1:0.5:2.75:180 for MIL-79 and 1:1:2.5:180 for MIL-80. The resulting gels were aged at 120 °C for 3 days in a Teflon-lined PARR bomb and cooled to room temperature. The pH remained acidic throughout the synthesis in both cases (pH 2-3). The white solids were filtered, washed, and dried at room temperature. The yttrium form doped with europium MIL-79(Y, Eu) was prepared using the same synthesis conditions as MIL-79 but substituting 98% of the initial europium nitrate precursor by yttrium nitrate Y(NO3)3⋅5H2O (Aldrich, 99.9%).

elements.content: As MIL-80 could not be obtained pure, i.e., without powder from MIL-79, analysis concerned only powder from MIL-79. TGA experiments, performed under air atmosphere on MIL-79 using a TA-Instrument type 2050 analyzer apparatus have shown several weight losses in the 273−873 K range. The residual solid has been identified as europium oxide Eu2O3. MIL-79 exhibits two weight losses of 10.6% and 27.3% at 373 and 673 K corresponding, respectively, to the departure of free water and bound water, part of the hydroxyl groups, and the organic moieties, followed by their partial replacement by oxygen atoms to form europium oxide at higher temperatures. These losses are on the whole in agreement with the theoretical values (9.1 and 33.5%). In the case of MIL-79(Y, Eu), a very similar TGA is observed (see Supporting Information) and losses are in agreement with the theoretical values (obsvd 14.9 and 32.5%; calcd, 12.0 and 36.7%).
elements.clean_text: As MIL-80 could not be obtained pure, i.e., without powder from MIL-79, analysis concerned only powder from MIL-79. TGA experiments, performed under air atmosphere on MIL-79 using a TA-Instrument type 2050 analyzer apparatus have shown several weight losses in the 273-873 K range. The residual solid has been identified as europium oxide Eu2O3. MIL-79 exhibits two weight losses of 10.6% and 27.3% at 373 and 673 K corresponding, respectively, to the departure of free water and bound water, part of the hydroxyl groups, and the organic moieties, followed by their partial replacement by oxygen atoms to form europium oxide at higher temperatures. These losses are on the whole in agreement with the theoretical values (9.1 and 33.5%). In the case of MIL-79(Y, Eu), a very similar TGA is observed (see Supporting Information) and losses are in agreement with the theoretical values (obsvd 14.9 and 32.5%; calcd, 12.0 and 36.7%).

elements.content: The infrared spectra of MIL-79 clearly show the presence of the vibrational bands characteristic of the −(O−C−O)− groups around 1550 and 1430 cm-1 confirming the presence of the dicarboxylate within the solids. Large bands around 3500 cm-1 also confirmed the presence of OH and/or H2O groups in MIL-79.
elements.clean_text: The infrared spectra of MIL-79 clearly show the presence of the vibrational bands characteristic of the -(O-C-O)- groups around 1550 and 1430 cm-1 confirming the presence of the dicarboxylate within the solids. Large bands around 3500 cm-1 also confirmed the presence of OH and/or H2O groups in MIL-79.

elements.content:
X-ray thermodiffractometry, performed in the furnace of a Siemens D-5000 diffractometer in the θ−θ mode, shows several steps in the decomposition for MIL-79.

Europium and carbon contents were determined for MIL-79(Eu) at the C.N.R.S. Central Laboratory of Analysis of Vernaison (69, France); the Eu and C contents are 52.6(3) and 10.3(4)%, which is, on the whole, in agreement with the theoretical values (49.5 and 9.40%). Similar results were obtained for MIL-79(Y, Eu):  34.9 and 11.8% for Y and C contents (theoretical:  35 and 11.4%) and 0.83% for Eu.
elements.clean_text:
X-ray thermodiffractometry, performed in the furnace of a Siemens D-5000 diffractometer in the θ-θ mode, shows several steps in the decomposition for MIL-79. 

Europium and carbon contents were determined for MIL-79(Eu) at the C.N.R.S. Central Laboratory of Analysis of Vernaison (69, France); the Eu and C contents are 52.6(3) and 10.3(4)%, which is, on the whole, in agreement with the theoretical values (49.5 and 9.40%). Similar results were obtained for MIL-79(Y, Eu): 34.9 and 11.8% for Y and C contents (theoretical: 35 and 11.4%) and 0.83% for Eu.

elements.content: X-ray electron diffraction was also performed on MIL-79(Y, Eu) using a JEOL 5800LV apparatus; five different analyses were realized giving a ratio Eu/(Eu+Y) between 1.3 and 1.5% (mean value:  1.4(1) %) confirming that the europium centers are homogeneously dispersed within the yttrium sub-network of MIL-79(Y, Eu).
elements.clean_text: X-ray electron diffraction was also performed on MIL-79(Y, Eu) using a JEOL 5800LV apparatus; five different analyses were realized giving a ratio Eu/(Eu+Y) between 1.3 and 1.5% (mean value: 1.4(1) %) confirming that the europium centers are homogeneously dispersed within the yttrium sub-network of MIL-79(Y, Eu).

elements.content: The luminescence excitation was provided by a Coherent Innova 300 argon laser and the fluorescence was dispersed through a HR1000 Jobin-Yvon monochromator. The signal was detected by a RTC 56 TVP photomultiplier and amplified by a PARR 128a lock-in amplifier with data acquisition on a microcomputer.
elements.clean_text: The luminescence excitation was provided by a Coherent Innova 300 argon laser and the fluorescence was dispersed through a HR1000 Jobin-Yvon monochromator. The signal was detected by a RTC 56 TVP photomultiplier and amplified by a PARR 128a lock-in amplifier with data acquisition on a microcomputer.

elements.content: Structure Determination. The hydrothermal synthesis of the title compounds led to powdered samples (MIL-79) or isolated single crystals (MIL-80). In the first case, a complex ab initio structure determination from X-ray powder data (39 independent atoms) was performed which required a simulated annealing program to locate the organic moieties. In the case of MIL-80, a standard structure determination from single-crystal data was conducted.
elements.clean_text:
Results

 Structure Determination. The hydrothermal synthesis of the title compounds led to powdered samples (MIL-79) or isolated single crystals (MIL-80). In the first case, a complex ab initio structure determination from X-ray powder data (39 independent atoms) was performed which required a simulated annealing program to locate the organic moieties. In the case of MIL-80, a standard structure determination from single-crystal data was conducted.

elements.content: (a) Structure of MIL-79 from Powder Data. The structure determination of MIL-79 from X-ray powder data was performed using a conventional high resolution (θ−2θ) Siemens D5000 Diffractometer with λCu Kα. The pattern was indexed in the monoclinic space group C2/m (Nο. 12), using the Dicvol program, with the following cell parameters:  a = 25.953(1) Å, b = 11.015(1) Å, c = 13.246(1) Å, and β = 119.16(1)°. Then, a direct method was realized using the Expo software to localize the europium atoms and some of the oxygen atoms. Because of the large cell volume and the light scattering power of carbon compared with europium, the FOX software, which combines a rigid body and a Monte Carlo approach in the real space, was used to find the position of the organic moieties. The free and bound water molecules were located by Fourier difference using Shelxtl. Finally, the whole structure was refined using Fullprof and its Winplotr package. Details of the structure determination are reported in Table and further information is provided in the Supporting Information.
elements.clean_text: (a) Structure of   MIL-79   from Powder Data. The structure determination of MIL-79 from X-ray powder data was performed using a conventional high resolution (θ-2θ) Siemens D5000 Diffractometer with λCu Kα. The pattern was indexed in the monoclinic space group C2/m (Nο. 12), using the Dicvol program, with the following cell parameters: a = 25.953(1) Å, b = 11.015(1) Å, c = 13.246(1) Å, and β = 119.16(1)°. Then, a direct method was realized using the Expo software to localize the europium atoms and some of the oxygen atoms. Because of the large cell volume and the light scattering power of carbon compared with europium, the FOX software, which combines a rigid body and a Monte Carlo approach in the real space, was used to find the position of the organic moieties. The free and bound water molecules were located by Fourier difference using Shelxtl. Finally, the whole structure was refined using Fullprof and its Winplotr package. Details of the structure determination are reported in Table  and further information is provided in the Supporting Information.

Crystal Data and Structure Refinement Parameters for MIL-79

formula Eu10O73C24H92 chemical formula weight (g·mol-1) 3068 calculated density (g·cm-3) 3.08 crystal system monoclinic space group C2/m a (Å) 25.953(1) b (Å) 11.015(1) c (Å) 13.246(1) β  (°) 119.16 (2) V (Å3) 3306.7(4) Z 2 figures of merit M 20 = 18; F 20 = 25 radiation (λCu (Å):  Kα1, Kα2) 1.54059, 1.54439 2θ range (°) 3−80 no. reflections 1088 no. atoms 39 no. intensity-dependent parameters 87 no. profile parameters 15 R P 0.095 R WP 0.128 R B 0.108 R F 0.095

The formula deduced from the structure determination for MIL-79 is Eu(III) 5(OH)9(H2O)6(O2C−C2H2−CO2)3· 9.5H2O. The final agreement factors are satisfactory for such a large and complex structure (39 independent atoms) using laboratory X-ray powder data:  R p = 9.5% and R Bragg/R F = 10.8%/9.5%. The final Rietveld plot is reported in Figure . Atomic coordinates and principal interatomic distances are provided in the Supporting Information.
elements.clean_text: The formula deduced from the structure determination for MIL-79 is Eu(III) 5(OH)9(H2O)6(O2C-C2H2-CO2)3⋅ 9.5H2O. The final agreement factors are satisfactory for such a large and complex structure (39 independent atoms) using laboratory X-ray powder data: R p = 9.5% and R Bragg/R F = 10.8%/9.5%. The final Rietveld plot is reported in Figure . Atomic coordinates and principal interatomic distances are provided in the Supporting Information.

elements.content: (b) Structure of MIL-80 from Single - Crystal Data. A rodlike single crystal of MIL-80 suitable for data collection was glued on a glass fiber. The intensity data were collected respectively on a Bruker-Siemens SMART three-circle diffractometer equipped with a CCD bidimensional detector, using the Mo Kα radiation. The reflections were corrected for Lorentz and polarization effects and absorption. The cell of MIL-80 is triclinic, space group P1̄ (No. 2). Details of the structure determination are given in Table .
elements.clean_text: (b) Structure of   MIL-80   from Single - Crystal Data. A rodlike single crystal of MIL-80 suitable for data collection was glued on a glass fiber. The intensity data were collected respectively on a Bruker-Siemens SMART three-circle diffractometer equipped with a CCD bidimensional detector, using the Mo Kα radiation. The reflections were corrected for Lorentz and polarization effects and absorption. The cell of MIL-80 is triclinic, space group P1̄ (No. 2). Details of the structure determination are given in Table .

Crystallographic Data forMIL-80

empirical formula Eu4O29C16H30 formula weight (g) 1294 temperature (K) 296 (2) wavelength (Å) 0.71073 crystal system triclinic space group P1̄ (Nο. 2) unit cell dimensions (Å) a = 10.5770 (2) b = 10.6164 (4) c = 14.9403 (3) β(°) = 113.892(1) volume (Å3) 1532.38 (5) multiplicity (z) 2 calculated density (mg/cm3) 2.805 absorption coefficient (mm-1) 8.337 F(000) 1896 crystal size 0.04*0.04*0.12 mm Theta range for data collection 1.36 to 30.03 deg. limiting indices −8 < h < 14,  −14 < k <14,  −20 < l < 20 reflections collected 11041 independent reflections 7799 (R int = 0.0437) refinement method full-matrix least-squares on F 2 data/restrainsts/parameters 7799/0/447 goodness-on-fit on F 2 0.935 final R indices [I > 2(I)] R 1 = 0.0475, wR 2 = 0.0889 R indices (all data) R 1 = 0.0833, wR 2 = 0.0989 extinction coefficient 0.00104(10) largest diff. peak and hole  1.980 and −1.956 e-·Å3

The structure was solved using the SHELXTL package. Europium and most of the oxygen and carbon atoms were first located, while the remaining carbon atoms and the water molecules were found using difference Fourier maps. Hydrogen atoms of the fumarate and maleate rings were fixed using distance and angles constraints, while hydrogen atoms bound to the μ3O oxygen atoms were found using Fourier difference maps. The final reliability factors44 converged to R 1(F) = 0.0475 and wR 2(F 2) = 0.089. Bond valence calculations confirm the oxidation state (+III) of europium. Finally, the formula deduced from the structure determination is EuIII 4(OH)4(H2O)5(O2C−C2H2−CO2)4·4H2O. Atomic coordinates, bond distances, and angles are provided in the Supporting Information.
elements.clean_text: The structure was solved using the SHELXTL package. Europium and most of the oxygen and carbon atoms were first located, while the remaining carbon atoms and the water molecules were found using difference Fourier maps. Hydrogen atoms of the fumarate and maleate rings were fixed using distance and angles constraints, while hydrogen atoms bound to the μ3O oxygen atoms were found using Fourier difference maps. The final reliability factors44 converged to R 1(F) = 0.0475 and wR 2(F 2) = 0.089. Bond valence calculations confirm the oxidation state (+III) of europium. Finally, the formula deduced from the structure determination is EuIII 4(OH)4(H2O)5(O2C-C2H2-CO2)4⋅4H2O. Atomic coordinates, bond distances, and angles are provided in the Supporting Information.

elements.content: The structures of MIL-79 and MIL-80 are three-dimensional (Figure ). They are built up from complex chains of Eu(III) polyhedra, linked in the two other directions by fumarate (trans configuration) or maleate moieties (cis configuration).
elements.clean_text:
Discussion

The structures of MIL-79 and MIL-80 are three-dimensional (Figure ). They are built up from complex chains of Eu(III) polyhedra, linked in the two other directions by fumarate (trans configuration) or maleate moieties (cis configuration).

elements.content: (a) View of the structure ofMIL-79 along the b axis. (b) View of the structure of MIL-80 along the c axis. Europium polyhedra, carbon atoms from the fumarate and maleate moieties are in gray and black, respectively. Free water molecules have been omitted for a better understanding.
elements.clean_text: 2  (a) View of the structure ofMIL-79 along the b axis. (b) View of the structure of MIL-80 along the c axis. Europium polyhedra, carbon atoms from the fumarate and maleate moieties are in gray and black, respectively. Free water molecules have been omitted for a better understanding.

elements.content: Compared to other rare-earth hybrids, the topologies of these chains are unique. It consists, in the case of MIL-79 (Figures and ), of a central core trans-chain of corner-shared bicapped square antiprisms Eu(1) (10-fold coordination) “coated” by rings of four face-sharing 8-fold (Eu(5)) and 9-fold (Eu(2−4)) coordinated polyhedra, which all share one face with those of the central chain. The chains of MIL-80 are built up from the edge-sharing linkage of supertetrahedra made from four 8- or 9-coordinated europium polyhedra (Figures and ). As proved by bond valence calculations, these face-sharings imply μ3-OH groups in both cases, and in MIL-79 some very unusual μ6-OH which correspond to the common vertexes O(5) and O(6) within the central chain (Figure ). Very scarce in hybrid solids, this special coordination is encountered as μ6-Cl in rare-earth chlorides and in the [Ln6−μ6O−(μ3OH)8]8+ rare- earth cluster reported previously. Thus, the inorganic network of MIL-79 is a reminiscence of these hexameric clusters and could be described as the linkage of truncated rare-earth Ln6−μ6O clusters. In MIL-80, the one-dimensional inorganic network comes directly from the edge-sharing linkage of tetrahedral [Ln4−(μ3OH)4]8+ clusters of polyhedra (Figure ). In both cases, the three-dimensionality of the framework is ensured by the dicarboxylates. The completion of the coordination of the rare-earth atoms is realized by oxygen atoms from the carboxylates and terminal water molecules. The latter are located at the periphery of the four-membered ring of the complex chain (MIL-79) or the supertetrahedra (MIL-80). It is noteworthy that the number of bound water molecules per rare-earth varies from one to three in both cases. All the interatomic distances are usual:  Eu−O (2.22−2.79 Å for MIL-79 and 2.32−2.73 Å for MIL-80), as well as C−O (1.19−1.40 Å (MIL79) and 1.21−1.27 Å (MIL-80)) and C−C distances (1.30−1.53 Å (MIL-79) and 1.29−1.49 Å (MIL-80)).
elements.clean_text: Compared to other rare-earth hybrids, the topologies of these chains are unique. It consists, in the case of MIL-79 (Figures  and ), of a central core trans-chain of corner-shared bicapped square antiprisms Eu(1) (10-fold coordination) "coated" by rings of four face-sharing 8-fold (Eu(5)) and 9-fold (Eu(2-4)) coordinated polyhedra, which all share one face with those of the central chain. The chains of MIL-80 are built up from the edge-sharing linkage of supertetrahedra made from four 8- or 9-coordinated europium polyhedra (Figures  and ). As proved by bond valence calculations, these face-sharings imply μ3-OH groups in both cases, and in MIL-79 some very unusual μ6-OH which correspond to the common vertexes O(5) and O(6) within the central chain (Figure ). Very scarce in hybrid solids, this special coordination is encountered as μ6-Cl in rare-earth chlorides and in the [Ln6-μ6O-(μ3OH)8]8+ rare- earth cluster reported previously. Thus, the inorganic network of MIL-79 is a reminiscence of these hexameric clusters and could be described as the linkage of truncated rare-earth Ln6-μ6O clusters. In MIL-80, the one-dimensional inorganic network comes directly from the edge-sharing linkage of tetrahedral [Ln4-(μ3OH)4]8+ clusters of polyhedra (Figure ). In both cases, the three-dimensionality of the framework is ensured by the dicarboxylates. The completion of the coordination of the rare-earth atoms is realized by oxygen atoms from the carboxylates and terminal water molecules. The latter are located at the periphery of the four-membered ring of the complex chain (MIL-79) or the supertetrahedra (MIL-80). It is noteworthy that the number of bound water molecules per rare-earth varies from one to three in both cases. All the interatomic distances are usual: Eu-O (2.22-2.79 Å for MIL-79 and 2.32-2.73 Å for MIL-80), as well as C-O (1.19-1.40 Å (MIL79) and 1.21-1.27 Å (MIL-80)) and C-C distances (1.30-1.53 Å (MIL-79) and 1.29-1.49 Å (MIL-80)).

elements.content: Structural subunits ofMIL-79 (a) and MIL-80 (b). Europium, carbon atoms, hydroxyl groups, and water molecules are in dark gray, black, white (empty), and white (cross-hatch), respectively, while oxygen atoms bound to carboxylate moieties are in medium gray.
elements.clean_text: 4  Structural subunits ofMIL-79 (a) and MIL-80 (b). Europium, carbon atoms, hydroxyl groups, and water molecules are in dark gray, black, white (empty), and white (cross-hatch), respectively, while oxygen atoms bound to carboxylate moieties are in medium gray.

elements.content: In MIL-79, the two isomers fumarate (trans) and maleate (cis) anions are present with a two-to-one ratio (see fumarate C(1)−C(4) and maleate C(5)−C(8)), whereas only fumarate moieties are present in MIL-80. Thus, during the hydrothermal synthesis of MIL-79, as the starting material is fumaric acid, an isomerization process occurs. In MIL-79, each organic group possesses one bidentate and one monodentate −CO2 function; in MIL-80, half of the fumarate moieties exhibit only −CO2 groups chelating two rare earth centers while the remaining carboxylate groups possess one oxygen atom connecting a rare-earth cation and one terminal −C−O function. In both structures, the free oxygen atoms of the carboxylates (O(8), O(14) for MIL-79 and O(18), O(20) for MIL-80) point toward the tunnels or the cages.
elements.clean_text: In MIL-79, the two isomers fumarate (trans) and maleate (cis) anions are present with a two-to-one ratio (see fumarate C(1)-C(4) and maleate C(5)-C(8)), whereas only fumarate moieties are present in MIL-80. Thus, during the hydrothermal synthesis of MIL-79, as the starting material is fumaric acid, an isomerization process occurs. In MIL-79, each organic group possesses one bidentate and one monodentate -CO2 function; in MIL-80, half of the fumarate moieties exhibit only -CO2 groups chelating two rare earth  centers while the remaining carboxylate groups possess one oxygen atom connecting a rare-earth cation and one terminal -C-O function. In both structures, the free oxygen atoms of the carboxylates (O(8), O(14) for MIL-79 and O(18), O(20) for MIL-80) point toward the tunnels or the cages.

elements.content: In MIL-79, the connection of these chains via the carboxylate ions creates interconnected tunnels in the three directions, the most important ones being along [010]. The free water molecules, inserted in the tunnels, give numerous hydrogen bonds with the terminal H2O molecules of the skeleton, which point toward the center of the tunnels. With such an arrangement, the appearance of a noticeable porosity could be expected (with free dimensions 2.8 * 8 Å for the tunnels) after the evacuation of the free and/or bound water molecules. Unfortunately, both TGA and thermodiffractometry (Figure ) show that all the water molecules evacuate the structure at the same time, in agreement with the presence of strong hydrogen bonds between the terminal and the templated H2O molecules. The irreversible dehydration corresponds to an important contraction of the cell and a decrease of the crystallinity. On the basis of the evolution of the position of the (100) and (002) reflections, the volume of the cell decreases by ca. 25% (V hydrated = 3306 Å3; V anhyd. = 2450 Å3), before the collapse of the structure at 573 K, giving rise to Eu2O3. This decrease also explains why the BET surface area measurement on the sample outgassed at 100 °C, using nitrogen as the adsorbed gas, does not indicate any porosity (S = 8 m2/g). Such a contraction was previously observed for the europium terephthalate MIL-51lt 35 and is probably due to the linkage of the free −CO groups to the rare-earth when terminal water molecules leave.
elements.clean_text: In MIL-79, the connection of these chains via the carboxylate ions creates interconnected tunnels in the three directions, the most important ones being along [010]. The free water molecules, inserted in the tunnels, give numerous hydrogen bonds with the terminal H2O molecules of the skeleton, which point toward the center of the tunnels. With such an arrangement, the appearance of a noticeable porosity could be expected (with free dimensions 2.8 * 8 Å for the tunnels) after the evacuation of the free and/or bound water molecules. Unfortunately, both TGA and thermodiffractometry (Figure ) show that all the water molecules evacuate the structure at the same time, in agreement with the presence of strong hydrogen bonds between the terminal and the templated H2O molecules. The irreversible dehydration corresponds to an important contraction of the cell and a decrease of the crystallinity. On the basis of the evolution of the position of the (100) and (002) reflections, the volume of the cell decreases by ca. 25% (V hydrated = 3306 Å3; V anhyd. = 2450 Å3), before the collapse of the structure at 573 K, giving rise to Eu2O3. This decrease also explains why the BET surface area measurement on the sample outgassed at 100 °C, using nitrogen as the adsorbed gas, does not indicate any porosity (S = 8 m2/g). Such a contraction was previously observed for the europium terephthalate MIL-51lt 35 and is probably due to the linkage of the free -CO groups to the rare-earth when terminal water molecules leave.

elements.content: X-ray thermodiffractogram ofMIL-79 under air.
elements.clean_text: 5  X-ray thermodiffractogram ofMIL-79 under air.

elements.content: In MIL-80, free water molecules occupy cages interacting with bound water molecules and free oxygen atoms from the monodendate carboxylates. No TGA and/or X-ray thermodiffractometry could be however performed to study the thermal behavior and the porosity of this solid, as MIL-80 could not be isolated in a pure form.
elements.clean_text: In MIL-80, free water molecules occupy cages interacting with bound water molecules and free oxygen atoms from the monodendate carboxylates. No TGA and/or X-ray thermodiffractometry could be however performed to study the thermal behavior and the porosity of this solid, as MIL-80 could not be isolated in a pure form.

elements.content: Optical Properties. To study the optical properties of MIL-79 upon radiation at room temperature, the isostructural yttrium form doped with 1.4% Eu (MIL-79(Y, Eu)) was prepared. The patterns of the two phases are very close; a cell indexing performed for MIL-79(Y, Eu) using Dicvol leads also to cell parameters very close to those of MIL-79, despite a small contraction due to the substitution (see Supporting Information). TGA and quantitative analysis also confirmed that MIL-79(Y, Eu) is isostructural with MIL-79 (see Supporting Information). Finally, the characteristic luminescence of Eu3+ ions is observed at room temperature in MIL-79(Y, Eu) under blue light. The luminescence spectrum recorded with an excitation at 465.8 nm provided by an argon laser is represented in Figure . The transitions observed between 580 and 740 nm are ascribed to the 5D0→7FJ (J = 0,1,2,3,4) transitions. At least four emission lines are observed for the nondegenerated 5D0→7F0 transition which indicates the presence of at least four sites of symmetry (Cs, Cn, or Cnv) for the Eu3+ ions within the compound.
elements.clean_text: Optical Properties. To study the optical properties of MIL-79 upon radiation at room temperature, the isostructural yttrium form doped with 1.4% Eu (MIL-79(Y, Eu)) was prepared. The patterns of the two phases are very close; a cell indexing performed for MIL-79(Y, Eu) using Dicvol leads also to cell parameters very close to those of MIL-79, despite a small contraction due to the substitution (see Supporting Information). TGA and quantitative analysis also confirmed that MIL-79(Y, Eu) is isostructural with MIL-79 (see Supporting Information). Finally, the characteristic luminescence of Eu3+ ions is observed at room temperature in MIL-79(Y, Eu) under blue light. The luminescence spectrum recorded with an excitation at 465.8 nm provided by an argon laser is represented in Figure . The transitions observed between 580 and 740 nm are ascribed to the 5D0→7FJ (J = 0,1,2,3,4) transitions. At least four emission lines are observed for the nondegenerated 5D0→7F0 transition which indicates the presence of at least four sites of symmetry (Cs, Cn, or Cnv) for the Eu3+ ions within the compound.

elements.content: Fluorescence spectra ofMIL-79(Y, Eu) at room temperature (excitation at 467 nm).
elements.clean_text: 6  Fluorescence spectra ofMIL-79(Y, Eu) at room temperature (excitation at 467 nm).

elements.content: In a second step, a spectroscopic analysis of the different europium sites has been performed using the site selective spectroscopy. Several selective excitations in the level 5D0→7F0 allowed a simplification of the spectra (Figure ). The comparison between the splitting of the three Stark components of the 7F1 multiplet indicates significant differences in crystal field strength of the different sites, which is in agreement with results from the structure determination. Besides, the values obtained for crystal field parameter N v were much lower (200−1000 cm-1) than those obtained with luminescent oxides (>2000 cm-1) (see Supporting Information).
elements.clean_text: In a second step, a spectroscopic analysis of the different europium sites has been performed using the site selective spectroscopy. Several selective excitations in the level 5D0→7F0 allowed a simplification of the spectra (Figure ). The comparison between the splitting of the three Stark components of the 7F1 multiplet indicates significant differences in crystal field strength of the different sites, which is in agreement with results from the structure determination. Besides, the values obtained for crystal field parameter N v were much lower (200-1000 cm-1) than those obtained with luminescent oxides (>2000 cm-1) (see Supporting Information).

elements.content: Selective excitation ofMIL-79(Y, Eu) in the 5D0→7F1 domain observed in the 5D0→7F2 transition
elements.clean_text: 7  Selective excitation ofMIL-79(Y, Eu) in the 5D0→7F1 domain observed in the 5D0→7F2 transition

elements.content: These results are qualitative, and other experiments are on the way to compare these performances with those of other hybrid rare-earth solids. However, our results are interesting for several reasons. First, it is well-known that luminescence quantum efficiency decreases when rare-earth centers are too close to each other and as MIL-79 exhibits an extended one-dimensional inorganic sub-network, the europium-doped yttrium form of MIL-79 was prepared to obtain a higher fluorescence. This opens the way for the introduction of luminescence into hybrid solids with extended inorganic networks and higher thermal stability.
elements.clean_text: These results are qualitative, and other experiments are on the way to compare these performances with those of other hybrid rare-earth solids. However, our results are interesting for several reasons. First, it is well-known that luminescence quantum efficiency decreases when rare-earth centers are too close to each other and as MIL-79 exhibits an extended one-dimensional inorganic sub-network, the europium-doped yttrium form of MIL-79 was prepared to obtain a higher fluorescence. This opens the way for the introduction of luminescence into hybrid solids with extended inorganic networks and higher thermal stability.

elements.content: Second, MIL-79(Y, Eu) is hydrated which usually quenches the luminescence quantum efficiency. However, the luminescence observed for MIL-79(Y, Eu) is quite efficient, this is probably due to the presence of organic linker with delocalized π electrons (fumarate and maleate moieties) which enhances the optical activity.
elements.clean_text: Second, MIL-79(Y, Eu) is hydrated which usually quenches the luminescence quantum efficiency. However, the luminescence observed for MIL-79(Y, Eu) is quite efficient, this is probably due to the presence of organic linker with delocalized π electrons (fumarate and maleate moieties) which enhances the optical activity.

elements.content: Finally, we report the synthesis and structure determination from X-ray powder or single crystal data of two new open-framework rare-earth hybrid solids, built up from unusual complex one-dimensional inorganic subnetworks made from clusters of rare-earth polyhedra, and unsaturated organic dicarboxylates. One of these solids exhibits luminescence properties when yttrium doped with europium is used as the metal source. Other similar compounds are currently under study to enlarge the field of luminescent hybrid phases based on rare-earth metals.
elements.clean_text: Finally, we report the synthesis and structure determination from X-ray powder or single crystal data of two new open-framework rare-earth hybrid solids, built up from unusual complex one-dimensional inorganic subnetworks made from clusters of rare-earth polyhedra, and unsaturated organic dicarboxylates. One of these solids exhibits luminescence properties when yttrium doped with europium is used as the metal source. Other similar compounds are currently under study to enlarge the field of luminescent hybrid phases based on rare-earth metals.

elements.content: Tables of crystal parameters, atomic positions and distances, X-ray patterns, and additional luminescence results (pdf), and crystallographic data (cif). This material is available free of charge via the Internet at http://pubs.acs.org. X-ray crystallographic data for MIL-80 are also available at the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre (Deposit CCDC 227996).

This material is available free of charge via the Internet at http://pubs.acs.org. X-ray crystallographic data for MIL-80 are also available at the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre (Deposit CCDC 227996).

elements.content: <title>References</title>
elements.clean_text: References

cln_elements.content: MIL-79 and MIL-80 were first prepared by mixing at room-temperature europium nitrate Eu(NO3)3·6H2O (Aldrich, 99.9%), fumaric acid HO2C−C2H2−CO2H (Aldrich, 99%), sodium hydroxide (Alfa, 97%), and deionized water in the following ratios:  1:0.5:2.75:180 for MIL-79 and 1:1:2.5:180 for MIL-80. The resulting gels were aged at 120 °C for 3 days in a Teflon-lined PARR bomb and cooled to room temperature. The pH remained acidic throughout the synthesis in both cases (pH 2−3). The white solids were filtered, washed, and dried at room temperature. The yttrium form doped with europium MIL-79(Y, Eu) was prepared using the same synthesis conditions as MIL-79 but substituting 98% of the initial europium nitrate precursor by yttrium nitrate Y(NO3)3·5H2O (Aldrich, 99.9%).
cln_elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

 MIL-79 and MIL-80 were first prepared by mixing at room-temperature europium nitrate Eu(NO3)3⋅6H2O (Aldrich, 99.9%), fumaric acid HO2C-C2H2-CO2H (Aldrich, 99%), sodium hydroxide (Alfa, 97%), and deionized water in the following ratios: 1:0.5:2.75:180 for MIL-79 and 1:1:2.5:180 for MIL-80. The resulting gels were aged at 120 °C for 3 days in a Teflon-lined PARR bomb and cooled to room temperature. The pH remained acidic throughout the synthesis in both cases (pH 2-3). The white solids were filtered, washed, and dried at room temperature. The yttrium form doped with europium MIL-79(Y, Eu) was prepared using the same synthesis conditions as MIL-79 but substituting 98% of the initial europium nitrate precursor by yttrium nitrate Y(NO3)3⋅5H2O (Aldrich, 99.9%).

cln_elements.content: As MIL-80 could not be obtained pure, i.e., without powder from MIL-79, analysis concerned only powder from MIL-79. TGA experiments, performed under air atmosphere on MIL-79 using a TA-Instrument type 2050 analyzer apparatus have shown several weight losses in the 273−873 K range. The residual solid has been identified as europium oxide Eu2O3. MIL-79 exhibits two weight losses of 10.6% and 27.3% at 373 and 673 K corresponding, respectively, to the departure of free water and bound water, part of the hydroxyl groups, and the organic moieties, followed by their partial replacement by oxygen atoms to form europium oxide at higher temperatures. These losses are on the whole in agreement with the theoretical values (9.1 and 33.5%). In the case of MIL-79(Y, Eu), a very similar TGA is observed (see Supporting Information) and losses are in agreement with the theoretical values (obsvd 14.9 and 32.5%; calcd, 12.0 and 36.7%).
cln_elements.clean_text: As MIL-80 could not be obtained pure, i.e., without powder from MIL-79, analysis concerned only powder from MIL-79. TGA experiments, performed under air atmosphere on MIL-79 using a TA-Instrument type 2050 analyzer apparatus have shown several weight losses in the 273-873 K range. The residual solid has been identified as europium oxide Eu2O3. MIL-79 exhibits two weight losses of 10.6% and 27.3% at 373 and 673 K corresponding, respectively, to the departure of free water and bound water, part of the hydroxyl groups, and the organic moieties, followed by their partial replacement by oxygen atoms to form europium oxide at higher temperatures. These losses are on the whole in agreement with the theoretical values (9.1 and 33.5%). In the case of MIL-79(Y, Eu), a very similar TGA is observed (see Supporting Information) and losses are in agreement with the theoretical values (obsvd 14.9 and 32.5%; calcd, 12.0 and 36.7%).

| largest diff. peak and hole | 1.980 and −1.956 e<sup>-</sup>·Å<sup>3</sup> |
<END>
